title: All the new movies and TV shows streaming in November
author: Kevin Slane
bullets: Netflix adds 'Stranger Things' Season 5 and Guillermo del Toro's 'Frankenstein' in November 2025.
HBO Max premieres Chris Evans' 'Materialists' on November 7 and Ari Aster's 'Eddington' on November 14.
Disney+ releases 'Fantastic Four: First Steps' as part of its November offerings.

title: Tom Brady refuses to pick sides in Patriots Buccaneers matchup
author: Aidan Buchanan
bullets: Tom Brady refuses to choose a side in upcoming Patriots vs. Buccaneers game, both former teams in top positions.
Patriots (7-2) face Buccaneers (6-2) in Tampa, both leading divisions and in Brady’s NFL top 10 rankings.
Brady to broadcast Lions vs. Commanders instead but praises Patriots' recent form and six-game win streak.

title: South Shore woman loses over $30,000 in arrest warrant scam
author: Madison Lucchesi
bullets: A Weymouth woman was scammed out of $31,600 by someone posing as a lieutenant with a fake arrest warrant.
The victim made payments of $20,500, $6,500, $4,500, and $100 to the scammer via wire transfer and Apple Pay.
Norfolk County Sheriff warns that the office and local police do not make calls demanding payments for arrest warrants.

title: 29-year-old driver killed in crash that closed Route 1 Wednesday morning
author: John Waller
bullets: A 29-year-old driver died in a crash on Route 1 in Norwood early Wednesday morning.
The incident led to the closure of Route 1 in both directions until it reopened shortly after 11 a.m.
A 47-year-old man involved in the crash was hospitalized with non-life-threatening injuries.

title: Boston police now required to wear nametags under new contract extension
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Boston patrol officers are required to wear nametags under a new contract extension with the city.
The contract, covering July 2025 to June 2026, also includes wage increases and free gym access for officers.
Mayor Michelle Wu highlighted the nametag rule as a step towards transparency and improving public trust in police.

title: The backlash has arrived: 6 takeaways from a good night for Democrats
author: Reid J. Epstein, The New York Times
bullets: Democrats won statewide elections in Virginia, New Jersey, California, and Pennsylvania, signaling a strong wave against Trump.
Zohran Mamdani's election as NYC mayor showcases a progressive shift, with potential influence on upcoming Democratic strategies.
Trump's absence from the ballot correlates to strong Democratic performance in off-year elections, as seen in Virginia and New Jersey.

title: The Swedish candy craze has taken Boston by storm. Here’s where you can get it.
author: Madison Lucchesi
bullets: Swedish candy has surged in popularity in Boston following a viral TikTok from January 2024.
Madeleine's Candy Shop in Boston's South End features Swedish candy and a new soft-serve ice cream window.
The Sweetish Fish and lil sweet treat have expanded from New York, offering unique candies in Boston's Seaport and Newbury Street.

title: Few answers as Woburn-based Newpro files for bankruptcy after sudden shutdown
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Newpro, a Woburn-based home improvement company, closed abruptly on October 28, affecting employees and customers nationwide.
The company and its subsidiaries filed for bankruptcy in Delaware, impacting over 10 entities under Renovo Home Partners LLC.
Newpro did not issue a WARN notice, leaving the number of affected employees unclear; creditors' meeting set for December 12.

title: Snag 20% off JetBlue flights in December during this limited-time sale
author: Kristi Palma
bullets: JetBlue is offering a 20% discount on base fares for flights booked by Nov. 6 for travel Dec. 2-18.
The sale excludes Friday and Sunday travel and is limited to non-stop flights; taxes and fees are not included.
Travelers can also get up to 40% off on Vacation packages booked through Jan. 4, 2026, for travel until March 31, 2026.

title: WWII veteran’s remains are being returned to Weymouth
author: Madison Lucchesi
bullets: WWII veteran Alfred Langevin's remains to return to Weymouth 81 years after disappearing in Germany's Hürtgen Forest.
Langevin's remains identified through DNA testing with his nephew's help; exhumed from a cemetery in Belgium.
Funeral procession to pass through Weymouth with public viewing at Town Hall; burial with military honors at Fairmount Cemetery.
